This happens if we have a bunch of unresolved issues or trauma that bogs us down, and we find ourselves defensive or triggered often by daily occurances, we cannot respond to these with openness or full responsiveness, because we have shut ourselves down due to the fight, flight or freeze reaction. (I more and more think that the key to unconscious/ consciousness exploration is linked with the parasympathetic nervous system response. And that neuroscience is finding out what religion has said for a long time - that love is consciousness, the higher path, awareness.... it is only when we feel the safety of being loved that we can actually open our awareness with our higher faculties). And so many are stuck in this trap. Or puzzle or maze like an escape room. It is like a trap, because interestingly, we cannot truly figure out this unconscious reactivity this defensive triggered survival mode while we are actually in it. Neuroscience is saying this too. That you feel safe again first. THEN look at understanding the trigger. But first, get out of the hole you are in, to see from a wider perspective. Often, we get trapped in the survivalist mode because we try to figure it out from within that survivalist mode. For example, someone who feels triggered by another’s behavior might then identify that behavior as the cause of the trigger. It merely cements the knowledge that the world is unsafe and that we have to have our defenses up instead of trying to find common ground. The tunnels I think are a metaphor similar to the "trances" they often talk about in the new age (and sometimes psychology). The auto pilot mode, that is living unconsciously, without conscious awareness and choice making. "Tunnel vision" is seeing only the narrowest path in front of you and no way out. This can be like depression "a long dark tunnel". Tunneling into something also in a more positive way can be about obsessive focus on figuring out the originating path of some particular behavioral pattern. Sometimes I think we do have to delve deeply into an obsessive thought on a specific topic in order to understand that pattern in our life. But, as in your dream, the idea is to recall you are not just in a negative obsessive circular thought pattern. But that instead you are "tunneling" up and out, in order to find the secret way to unlock this particular unconscious behavioral pattern, to crack the code, to be able to stop unconsciously repeating it.

comment_text: I think you are dreaming of your dad more and more because while the feeling of loss was raw and unprocessed, all you felt was the grief of his loss, and the palpable absence of this person. You felt "he is gone! He is not here!" And the pain of that was first and foremost. Now that you are processing the grief, you are moving back to the feeling of his presence, and the joy and comfort that you felt being together with him, the love he had for you. You always had the joy, love and comfort there too, underneath the pain of loss, but couldn't access it. Now you can open and access this joy again, because the grief is not making you turn away from the happiness that is there. Of course this is a scary process - opening to feeling comfort, joy, love, security, happiness, this is a reminder of how that good feeling is something that can be taken away. Which is frightening. And causes inner conflict "maybe I shouldn't feel the joy, because then it will hurt more if I lose that feeling". The dream is telling you, "you never lost that feeling, it has always been there and it always will be there. The joy is bigger than the grief. The pain turned you away from the joy, the joy never left" It is saying that your father, in this way, and also in how you are very much like him in many good ways, your father has never left you. Instead of feeling his absence, you are feeling his presence, as you open up to the positive attachment you felt with him, and as you open up to the side of yourself that is very much like your father. In the dreams, the contrast of being alone and being with family is a reminder that you are never truly alone when you have loved and been loved. For all those you connect with in life, you live in their hearts, as they live in yours. In this way, there is a life beyond death, time, and place.
